“Global warming” refers to the long-term warming of the planet.\n“Climate change” encompasses global warming, but refers to the broader range of changes that are happening to our planet.
All of these are problems associated with climate change. The majority of scientists agree that many of these effects are caused by human contribution to the greenhouse effect.

The Earth receives solar radiation from the sun. Passing through the atmosphere, some radiation is absorbed by the Earth, while some is reflected back to space. When the exchange of incoming and outgoing radiation occurs, some of the radiation becomes trapped by gases in the atmosphere. This creates a “greenhouse” effect and warms the planet.

Greenhouse gases may be a result of natural occurrence or human activity. These gases include water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, and ozone. Fluorinated gases are also considered to be greenhouse gases.
According to the EPA, China is currently the top emitter of carbon dioxide, accounting for 30% of global carbon emissions. The United States ranks as the second top emitter at 15%.

More than a third of food produced globally never makes it to the table. During the production, harvesting, transporting, and packaging of the wasted food, more than 3.3 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide is emitted.
The electricity and heat production sector emits the largest percentage of global greenhouse gas emissions at 25%. Agriculture, forestry, and other land use sector is a close second at 24%.

The average global temperature has risen by 0.94 degrees C since the twentieth century with more significant warming toward the poles than in the equatorial region.

The concentration of CO2 now is 407.62 parts per million (ppm). The last time CO2 concentration was so high was about 4m years ago, when the global temperature was 3C-4C hotter and sea level was 5-40m higher.
40% of Arctic ice area has been lost in the last few decades, one of the most obvious signs of global warming. It is at least 1,450 years since such melting occurred.
Satellite data shows global sea level has risen by more than 8cm since 1993, driven by melting ice and the warming of sea water, which expands its volume.

Russia and the United States are signatories of the 2015 Paris Accord as are most of the world’s nations. As of June 2017, only Nicaragua and Syria have not signed the Paris Accord with the United States planning to withdraw.

The Paris Agreement aims to keep the overall increase in global temperatures below 2 degrees Celsius, with the hope of limiting it to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Scientists believe that these are the largest increases in global temperature that we could experience without causing catastrophic change to the Earth’s climate.
